ANNEX (Written answers)
QUESTIONS TO THE COUNCIL (The Presidency-in-Office of the Council of the European Union bears sole responsibility for these answers)
Question no 1 by Bernd Posselt (H-0512/10)
 Subject: Sandžak of Novi Pazar
 

What is the Council’s opinion of the current political, socio-economic and human rights situation in the Serbian Sandžak of Novi Pazar, where there are serious problems relating to ethnic minorities?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) The Council has not discussed the situation in the Serbian region Sandžak and cannot comment on the issue.

However, the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA), which is currently being ratified, states that Serbia and the EU shall seek to strengthen regional and local development cooperation, with the objective of contributing to economic development and reducing regional imbalances. Specific attention shall be given to cross-border, transnational and interregional cooperation.

Allow me to add that the SAA also establishes close economic cooperation, including the development of a free trade area and financial cooperation that shall take due account of the priority areas related to the Community acquis in the field of regional development.

The Council has reaffirmed on many occasions its full support for the European perspective of the region, including Serbia, which remains essential for its stability, reconciliation and future. In accordance with the Stabilisation and Association process and particularly with the SAA, which is currently being ratified, the Council supports Serbia’s efforts to strengthen democracy and the rule of law, and to contribute to political, economic and institutional stability in Serbia, as well as to the stabilisation of the region.

The Council welcomes Serbia’s commitment to EU integration by undertaking key reforms in line with European standards. In recognition of these efforts, the Council has recently taken some important decisions with regard to Serbia: on 30 November 2009, the Council lifted visa restrictions; on 14 June 2010, it decided to begin ratifying the Stabilisation and Association Agreement and, on 25 October 2010, to begin the procedure laid down in Article 49 TEU.

As regards the protection of persons belonging to minorities, in accordance with the Copenhagen criteria, in December 2009, the Council stressed the importance of protection of all minorities and encouraged the governments of the Western Balkan countries, including the Serbian Government, to take the necessary action to address these issues. It added that the Roma minority continues to face very difficult living conditions and discrimination.

In its conclusions of 7 and 8 December 2009, the Council recalled that strengthening the rule of law, fight against corruption and accelerating economic reforms remain important, and that a constructive approach towards regional cooperation, including trade, remains essential. The reform agenda must be continued.

The specific priorities of the European Partnership with Serbia, adopted on 18 February 2008, also include human rights and protection of minorities. Serbia must therefore fulfil all obligations arising out of membership of the Council of Europe and must ensure compliance with the human rights provisions of the new constitution.

 

Question no 2 by Georgios Koumoutsakos (H-0516/10)
 Subject: Adoption of measures for the implementation of the solidarity clause
 

Over the last few days a number of countries (the USA, the United Kingdom, Australia, etc.) have issued travellers with urgent instructions informing them about the possible threat of a terrorist attack on public transport and/or at tourist sites in Europe. These developments give added importance to the ‘solidarity clause’ (TFEU, Article 222) and highlight the need to define the ‘arrangements for the implementation by the Union of the solidarity clause [...]defined by a decision adopted by the Council acting on a joint proposal by the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy’(Article 222, paragraph 3).

Given that the Belgian Presidency has included among the objectives of its programme the adoption of the measures necessary for the ‘solidarity clause’ to enter into effect as rapidly as possible, will the Council say: What stage have discussions reached on implementing the solidarity clause? Has it taken specific initiatives to this end and, if so, what is the timetable for their implementation, especially in view of the latest developments?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) The solidarity clause is one of the important innovations in the fight against terrorism introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon. Thus, Article 222(1) TFEU states that the Union and its Member States shall act jointly in a spirit of solidarity if a Member State is the object of a terrorist attack or the victim of a natural or man-made disaster.

In accordance with Article 222(3) TFEU, the Council shall adopt the arrangements for the implementation of Article 222 acting on a joint proposal by the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy.

The Commission has announced that a proposal will be tabled in 2011.

 

Question no 3 by Georgios Papanikolaou (H-0518/10)
 Subject: Growth and competitiveness
 

When announcing its programme, the Belgian Presidency placed special emphasis on the adoption of measures to restore the competitiveness and growth rates of the Member States. In particular, one of its basic priorities was to restore the markets' confidence in the single currency and the eurozone economies through the introduction of major institutional reforms.

Given that the Belgian Presidency is due to end in about one month’s time, to what extent have its initiatives and programme been implemented in the area of growth and competitiveness?

What are the Council’s estimates for the Member States’ growth rates in the forthcoming period, particularly those countries affected by the economic crisis?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) The economic and financial crisis, which began in 2008, has caused a sharp decline in the number of jobs and in potential output, and has led to a serious deterioration in public finances.

Against this backdrop of crisis, the June 2010 European Council adopted the Europe 2020 strategy, which is designed to guarantee smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, as evidenced by its objectives, relating in particular to employment, research and development, renewable energy and energy efficiency, early school leaving and poverty reduction.

In July, the Council, under the Belgian Presidency, adopted the broad economic policy guidelines for implementing the Europe 2020 strategy aimed at improving competitiveness via structural reforms.

At the same time, the Council began examining certain structural elements such as fiscal frameworks, the effectiveness of education as a vehicle for growth, and the sustainability of pensions.

On 21 October 2010, the Council also adopted the employment policy guidelines, in order to give precise guidance to the Member States on defining their National Reform Programmes and implementing reforms, reflecting interdependence and in line with the Stability and Growth Pact.

As regards economic governance, the European Council of 28 and 29 October 2010 endorsed the report of the Task Force on economic governance and called for a fast track approach to be followed on the adoption of secondary legislation needed for the implementation of many of the recommendations. This will enhance confidence and thus contribute to sustainable growth, employment and competitiveness. Therefore, in order to ensure balanced and sustainable growth, Heads of State or Government agree on the need for Member States to establish a permanent crisis mechanism to safeguard the financial stability of the euro area as a whole.

As regards growth rates, the Council has made no estimates. The latest interim report by the Commission estimates growth of 1.8% in the EU and 1.7% in the euro area in 2010.

 

Question no 4 by Marian Harkin (H-0523/10)
 Subject: Single Farm Payment
 

Can the Council ensure that any changes to the Single Farm Payment do not have sudden adverse effects on older farmers who depend on that payment?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) In the Communication ‘The CAP towards 2020(1)’, which it recently adopted, the Commission refers to the option of reviewing the direct payment system within the framework of the future post-2013 CAP.

In June 2009, the Council took note of Presidency conclusions, supported by a number of delegations, which stated that, in order to meet the challenges for agriculture after 2013, any future direct payments scheme will need to be fair and legitimate, effective, simple to implement, sufficiently flexible, and easy to justify and explain.

Furthermore, the Council has taken due note of the position expressed by the European Parliament in its Resolution on the future of the CAP, adopted on 8 July, and in particular of its recommendation that, in order to ensure a fair distribution of CAP funds to farmers across the EU, fair and objective criteria should be clearly defined for the implementation of a fair system of distribution that respects the diversity of farming in the EU.

I would draw the honourable Member’s attention to the fact that Commissioner Cioloş will present his Communication to the Council as early as Monday 29 November.

The Belgian Presidency attaches great importance to this issue, which is why it has scheduled a political debate for the Council meeting of 13-14 December 2010.

However, the Council will be able to express an opinion on the details of the issue of the fair distribution of direct payments only after it has received the legislative proposals that the Commission is due to submit to it and to the European Parliament in July 2011.

The European Parliament and the Council will then be required to make a decision, under the ordinary legislative procedure.

 
 

(1) COM (2010)672 of 18.11.2010.

 

Question no 5 by Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (H-0525/10)
 Subject: Illegal employment in the European Union
 

According to the objectives set out in the Belgian Presidency’s work programme and in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, the Member States are to undertake reforms in order to make progress towards achieving sustainable and transparent economic growth.

All Member States face the problems of illegal employment and unfair competition on the market. Workers on the labour market are exploited, often have no social protection and are also sometimes obliged to accept undeclared work.

High unemployment means that employers cannot find the workers they need because unemployment benefits are similar to the wages on offer. There are even situations where people prefer to work on the black, because that lets them continue to benefit from employment exchange services and not lose out on allowances. As a result, people generally choose the option that suits them best. The objectives set in Member States’ annual budgets are not achieved because the revenue forecast in these budgets is not collected.

Does the Belgian Presidency intend to take action and does it have plans for specific proposals on how Member States can combat illegal and undeclared work?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) Whereas Article 3(3) of the Treaty on European Union stipulates that the Union shall aim at full employment, Article 147 TFEU stipulates that the Union shall contribute to a high level of employment by encouraging cooperation between Member States and by supporting and, if necessary, complementing their action. In doing so, the competences of the Member States shall be respected.

To date, the Commission has submitted no legislative proposals to support or complement Member States’ actions aimed at combating the undeclared work of EU citizens.

However, on 21 October 2010, the Council, under the Belgian Presidency, adopted guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States; the latter will have to transpose them into their national policies via national reform programmes. Since those guidelines are aimed, in particular, at reducing structural unemployment and promoting job quality, it may be argued that they are designed to boost declared and legal work.

As regards the issue of illegally staying third-country nationals, the Council has recognised the importance of strengthening the measures to combat the employment of those persons in order to combat illegal immigration and undeclared work. Since that objective, namely to combat illegal immigration by acting against the employment pull factor, cannot be sufficiently achieved by the Member States, on 18 June 2009, the European Parliament and the Council adopted Directive 2009/52/EC providing for minimum standards on sanctions and measures against employers of illegally staying third-country nationals. The aim of that directive is to counteract illegal immigration by acting against the employment pull factor, an aim which both institutions agreed could not be sufficiently achieved by the Member States and therefore required a European directive. As far as sanctions are concerned, these should include in particular the employer’s contribution to the costs of returning illegally employed third-country nationals, with the possibility of reduced sanctions where the employer is a natural person who employs an illegally staying third-country national for his or her private purposes. The measures include, among other things, simplified procedures for employers, to enable the Member States to check the validity of residence permits or to check for forged documents. The Member States must take the measures necessary to comply with this directive by 20 July 2011.

 

Question no 6 by Gay Mitchell (H-0529/10)
 Subject: End of the recession
 

With economic activity beginning to pick up in some parts of Europe and the budget deficits of the Member States now being taken under control, does the Council believe that the recession has finally ended in the EU?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) According to the latest figures published by the European Commission (September 2010 interim forecast), gross domestic product (GDP) growth is forecast at 1.8% in the EU and 1.7% in the euro area in 2010. The figures confirmed for the first and second quarters of 2010 show that the rate of GDP growth in the 27 EU Member States was 0.3% and 0.7% respectively (the Council has not adopted a position on the issue of the recession). These figures would seem to indicate, according to a widespread definition of the recession, that the EU is no longer in recession.

However, looking to the future, a fall in GDP growth is forecast in the second half of 2010, due to the anticipated slowdown in the global economy. Consequently, the challenge for the future is to ensure that the EU continues to consolidate its growth while guaranteeing the strength and viability of public finances. This effort should be aimed at stabilising debt levels, and subsequently reducing them, in order to restore them initially to pre-crisis levels, and then to bring them within the limits laid down by the Stability and Growth Pact.

The Member States and the EU have made a huge contribution in budgetary terms to support the financial sector and the real economy, something which has naturally led to an increase in government deficits. These necessary and timely contributions have played an extremely important role in preventing a more serious crisis, while laying the foundations for future growth. Nevertheless, the crisis has shown that sound budgets are not enough to guarantee sustainable economic growth.

The package agreed by the Task Force, when validated by the European Council of 28 and 29 October 2010, will be the biggest reform of the Economic and Monetary Union since the euro was created.

The recommendations and concrete proposals contained in the report of the Task Force are aimed in particular at implementing a surveillance mechanism, as a macroeconomic pendant of the budget-focused Pact, in order to create an early warning system to detect the risk of real estate bubbles or of unsustainable patterns on the balance of payments, or strong divergences in competitiveness.

 

Question no 7 by Seán Kelly (H-0534/10)
 Subject: Adults on the move
 

We must remember that there are many adults affected by unemployment too. It is important to have a specialised programme for getting adults back into the labour market, through further training and lifelong learning programmes that will increase their skills.

Can the Council give details of any plans to facilitate an Adults on the Move programme similar to the Youth on the Move programme?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) Faced with the unacceptable level of youth unemployment, ‘Youth on the Move’ is one of the flagship initiatives forming part of the EU’s Europe 2020 strategy for employment and smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, adopted by the European Council on 17 June 2010. However, the EU’s Europe 2020 strategy concerns the entire population, with particular emphasis on women and men aged 20-64, the employment rate of whom is intended to increase to 75% under the strategy.

The Member States are responsible, in the first instance, for drafting and implementing their employment policies and, through those policies, they must contribute, among other things, to the achievement of the objectives laid down in the Europe 2020 strategy. The Europe 2020 strategy is based on a set of consistent guidelines on employment issues and broad economic policy issues.

On 21 October 2010, in accordance with Article 148 TFEU and on the basis of the conclusions of the European Council, the Council adopted the guidelines for the employment policies of the Member States, as part of the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy.

In this regard, Guideline 7 ‘Increasing labour market participation of women and men, reducing structural unemployment and promoting job quality’ emphasises that ‘employment services play an important role in activation and matching’ and that ‘such services should be open to all’.

Guideline 8 ‘Developing a skilled workforce responding to labour market needs and promoting lifelong learning’ reminds the Member States that initial education and vocational training must be complemented with effective incentives for lifelong learning for those who are not in employment, thus ensuring every adult the chance to retrain or to move one step up in their qualification. In particular, efforts should focus on supporting those with low and obsolete skills and on increasing the employability of older workers.

Lastly, Guideline 9 ‘Improving the performance of education and training systems at all levels and increasing participation in tertiary education’ provides that the Member States should invest efficiently in education and training systems notably to raise the skill level of the EU’s workforce, allowing it to meet the rapidly changing needs of modern labour markets. In line with the lifelong learning principles, action should cover all sectors (from early childhood education and schools through to higher education, vocational education and training, as well as adult learning). Reforms should aim to ensure the acquisition of the key competencies that every individual needs for success in a knowledge-based economy, notably in terms of employability, lifelong learning and information and communication technologies.

 

Question no 8 by Mairead McGuinness (H-0535/10)
 Subject: Child abduction and the Hague Convention
 

The Council is no doubt aware that child abduction is hugely distressing and potentially harmful to the child involved.

The foremost goal of the Hague Convention is to protect children from the harmful effects of their wrongful removal or retention and to establish procedures to ensure their prompt return to the state of their habitual residence, as well as to secure protection for rights of access. Sadly, the Convention does not work for everyone.

Does the Council believe there is a need for a more balanced interpretation of the Hague Convention across the Member States?

Does the Council believe there is benefit to be gained in Member States coordinating their approaches to cases of child abduction?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) The Council is fully aware that the wrongful removal or retention of a child is a distressing and potentially harmful experience for the child concerned.

The Council recognises that the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction is a highly important international instrument, which, it must be stressed, has enabled many child abduction cases to be solved since its adoption. Like the honourable Member, the Council is anxious to see this convention applied effectively, for the benefit of the children concerned.

The Council would point out that the European Union as such is not a contracting party to the Hague Convention. The Council notes, however, that the Member States, which are all contracting parties, exchange views and experiences within the framework of Special Commissions convened at regular intervals by the Hague Conference in order to monitor the practical operation of the convention.

In this context, the Council would also point out that the 1980 Convention was supplemented, in 1996, by another convention adopted by the Hague Conference. It should be mentioned that, in connection with the implementation of the latter convention, the Member States have cooperated closely in creating a practical guide of which some parts are specifically aimed at providing guidelines on the handling of child abduction cases.

As for the benefit to be gained from Member States coordinating their approaches to cases of child abduction, the Council would point out that such coordination already exists. Indeed, in their dealings with each other the Member States must apply Regulation (EC) No 2201/2003 concerning jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters and the matters of parental responsibility. This Brussels IIa Regulation contains, among other things, rules of jurisdiction on child abduction, in particular with regard to judgments requiring the return of a child who has been wrongfully removed or retained in a Member State other than the Member State where he or she was habitually resident.

 

Question no 9 by Nikolaos Chountis (H-0536/10)
 Subject: Memorandum and extension of repayment schedule for Greek debt
 

The Managing Director of the IMF has expressly and categorically stated that the Fund is prepared to extend the repayment schedule for the loans contracted by Greece from the financial mechanism, provided the Member States of the EU do likewise. The main reasons behind Mr Strauss-Kahn's statement are that the refinancing needs for the Greek debt will increase inordinately over the two-year period 2014-2015 and that there is a need to create a positive climate on the markets. The Greek population is apprehensive at the thought that extending the repayment schedule will prolong the unpopular policies implemented under the Memorandum.

In view of the IMF's proposal, is the Council prepared to put this matter on the agenda for the summit? Does the possible extension of the repayment schedule for Greece's loans also presuppose that the Memorandum will continue to apply beyond 2013?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) Following the deterioration in Greece’s macroeconomic and budgetary situation in 2010, the Council addressed some recommendations to Greece inviting it to adopt appropriate measures to reduce its budget deficit and to implement the necessary structural reforms.

Thus, on 10 May and 7 September 2010, the Council addressed two Decisions to Greece with a view to reinforcing and deepening fiscal surveillance and giving notice to Greece to take measures for the deficit reduction judged necessary to remedy the situation of excessive debt. The two Decisions set out the main elements of the economic programme that Greece will have to implement, and which reflects the key conditions attached to financial assistance.

The financial support programme for Greece has been agreed and implemented by the Member States of the euro area outside the EU treaties. It consists of a package of bilateral loans granted individually by those Member States of the euro area that are participating in the programme.

The conditions attached to the bilateral loans were the subject of a specific loan agreement between the Member States providing financial support and Greece, to which the Memorandum of Understanding is annexed. The Memorandum lays down the loan disbursement conditions.

Given the nature of the loans granted, the Council is not in a position to comment on Member States’ decisions.

 

Question no 10 by Zigmantas Balčytis (H-0542/10)
 Subject: GMO decision-making shift to national governments
 

The issue of the cultivation of GM crops is dealt with differently from Member State to Member State. However, the Commission has come up with a proposal to devolve decision-making on the authorisation of GMOs to national governments. Allowing authorisation by each country could mark the beginning of a re-nationalisation of EU policy and might have serious implications for the single market.

What is the position of the Belgian Presidency on this particular issue? Is the Presidency in favour of clear rules on the co-existence of GM and non-GM crops at EU level, with the Commission playing a major role, or in favour of decision-making at national level?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) The Presidency, being fully aware of the political sensitivity and technical complexity associated with this legislative initiative, organised two initial debates within the Council on 27 September and 14 October 2010.

As a result of these initial debates, it was found that some aspects of the Commission proposal still require clarification. In particular, following this preliminary examination within the Council, an ad hoc working group was set up with the specific task of preparing the technical elements of the legislative proposal, in particular with a view to clarifying the most important issues raised therein. These issues relate in particular to the legal basis that the Commission proposes to use in its proposal (Article 114 TFEU) and the compatibility of future national measures with the treaties and international trade rules (WTO).

The group will also have to focus on the risks that the Commission proposal may entail for compliance with the rules on the internal market, in particular as regards possible grounds for prohibiting GMOs within the various Member States.

 

Question no 11 by João Ferreira (H-0545/10)
 Subject: Adaptation to climate change and external debt of developing countries
 

At the end of 2009, the European Council decided that the EU and its Member States would contribute financing on an annual basis to adaptation to climate change in developing countries, in the form of ‘fast-start funding’ of EUR 2.4 billion per annum, for the period 2010-2012.

This sum corresponds to less than half what Parliament considered to be the necessary minimum for the period concerned (EUR 5-7 billion). It represents approximately 2% of what the EU itself estimates to be the annual costs of mitigation and adaptation for the period between 2012 and 2020. It also represents less than 1% of the value of the external debt of all of the African countries (on 2006 figures).

Can the Council state what amounts have been channelled so far to developing countries as 'fast-start funding' for the period 2010-2012? What sums will be transferred over the next two years? What concrete forms will this funding take? Is the Council considering the possibility of increasing the funding?

Does the Council not believe that the external debt and debt servicing of the least developed countries represents an enormous constraint on their development, which has already obliged them to dedicate a large proportion of their resources to servicing a dent which should, surely, now be written off?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) On 17 November 2010, the Council approved the report on ‘fast-start funding’ in accordance with the political agreement concluded at the December 2009 European Council(1). The confirmed total amount of funding to be channelled to developing countries as ‘fast-start funding’ for the year 2010 is EUR 2.2 billion. A total of EUR 7.2 billion has been set aside for the entire period 2010-2012. These commitments confirm the EU Member States’ compliance with the Copenhagen Agreement.

The Member States have made considerable progress in implementing the commitments for 2010. A non-exhaustive list of projects has been drawn up and disseminated by the Council. The Council will draft annual reports on ‘fast-start funding’ for the next two years.

The Council has called on the Economic and Financial Committee and the Economic Policy Committee to update the data in order to present the most comprehensive information possible at the Cancun Conference.

The Council has made no provision to increase the sums laid down in paragraph 1. The Council merely checks that the Member States are honouring their commitments. Since the ‘fast-start funding’ is a set of commitments made by the Member States, it is possible that some Member States will decide to increase their contributions.

EU action to mitigate or cancel the debt of developing countries is carried out as part of the HIPC (Heavily Indebted Poor Countries) Initiative and of the Multilateral Debt Relief Initiative (MDRI).

In its Conclusions of 11 November 2008(2), the Council reaffirmed the EU’s will to take action to help restore and preserve debt sustainability in low-income countries, in particular by acting, where possible in a coordinated manner, to prevent unsustainable lending behaviour by lenders which have not contributed to alleviating the burden of poor countries.

The EU is also committed to collectively provide technical assistance to strengthen the debt management capacities of debtor nations, and to assist efficient debt negotiations with non-Paris Club official bilateral creditors and commercial creditors.

The EU also stresses the importance of supporting enhanced democratic oversight regarding both the debt to be contracted in borrowing countries and the use of resources freed up through debt relief.

 
 

(1) Document EUCO 6/09 of 10/11 December 2009.
(2) 15480/08.

 

Question no 12 by Laima Liucija Andrikienė (H-0549/10)
 Subject: EU - South Africa trade relations
 

What are the prospects of South Africa concluding an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) with the EU? Has the EU-South Africa summit, held on 28 September 2010, provided any breakthroughs in this regard? What are the most acute obstacles and contentious issues in this process? What is the chance that such an agreement could be concluded before the end of this year?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) South Africa is participating, along with the other countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) – Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia and Swaziland – in the negotiations on an Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA). In this respect a new impetus can be observed in 2010.

Indeed, during the third EU-South Africa Summit, which took place on 28 September 2010, the political leaders engaged in frank and open discussions on the EU-SADC EPA and, at the same time, reaffirmed their will and determination to conclude negotiations on an Economic Partnership Agreement that enhances the trade and economic relations between the SADC and the EU.

The leaders welcomed the timetable of negotiations planned until the end of the year. They urged both sides to reach a mutually satisfactory conclusion of all remaining issues.

Our shared objective to conclude the negotiations by the end of 2010 is certainly ambitious, but it is within our reach. It will, of course, require effort, a serious commitment and a spirit of compromise from both partners.

Since the Summit, the negotiators have already met and will meet again. I am convinced that, thanks to the political momentum provided by the Summit, the negotiators will be able to find a solution to the outstanding issues.

South Africa is the biggest economy in the region, and it must therefore play a leading role. I am confident about the prospects of concluding an agreement by the end of the year.

 

Question no 13 by Pat the Cope Gallagher (H-0551/10)
 Subject: The Small Business Act
 

The review of the Small Business Act is a priority of the Belgian Presidency of the EU. Can the Council outline what actions it has undertaken to review this initiative so as to improve the competitiveness of SMEs in the EU?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) The Communication ‘A ‘Small Business Act’ for Europe’ (SMA), adopted by the Commission on 25 June 2008, aims to place SMEs at the heart of policy-making (‘Think Small First’), to increase their capacity to create jobs within the EU and to stimulate their competitiveness within the single market and the world markets alike.

On 1 December 2008, the Council adopted conclusions approving the Commission’s approach and calling on the Commission and the Member States to ensure its implementation and ongoing monitoring.

In its report of 15 December 2009, the Commission outlined the progress made in implementing the SBA and announced its intention to publish a communication in December 2010, once it had consulted representatives of SME professional bodies and the competent public authorities. The Council is awaiting this communication so as to decide on what follow-up action, if any, to take.

Furthermore, under the Belgian Presidency, the Council has made progress on matters of great importance for SMEs: the functioning of the internal market and the ‘Single Market Act’ project; the new innovation strategy; the concrete measures for European tourism approved by the Council; and the simplification of European research programmes to enable innovative SMEs to access financing more quickly.

We have had success: the adoption, in conjunction with the European Parliament, of the directive on combating late payment in commercial transactions is a huge success as far as SMEs are concerned, and we welcome the European Parliament’s unfailing spirit of cooperation, which has made this outcome possible.

The Council would also point out that the work in relation to the consolidation and appropriate regulation of the financial sector is being undertaken with the aim of improving access to capital for SMEs, the businesses most affected by the credit crunch.

 

Question no 14 by Brian Crowley (H-0553/10)
 Subject: EU-US Summit - 20 November 2010
 

Can the Council provide an overview of the key political agreements reached at the recent EU-US Summit on 20 November 2010?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) The EU-US Summit on 20 November was a great success. The discussions between Presidents Obama, Van Rompuy and Barroso were of a very high quality.

On the economy, the European Union and the United States discussed the results of the G20 summit in Seoul, and the contribution the European Union and the United States can make to securing a sustainable and balanced recovery and to creating jobs through structural financial market reform and fiscal consolidation which promotes growth.

The European Union and the United States stressed the need to fully tap into the potential of transatlantic commerce to boost growth and generate jobs on both sides of the Atlantic. The European Union and the United States recognise the central role of the Transatlantic Economic Council (TEC) in achieving these objectives, and they tasked the TEC to develop a transatlantic innovation agenda to stimulate growth and create jobs in areas such as clean energy, e-health, information and communication, and other emerging technologies. The TEC is expected to report on progress in these areas in the first half of 2011.

The European Union and the United States emphasised that they stand by the commitments they made in Copenhagen last December to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The European Union and the United States agreed to promote a positive outcome at the Cancun conference.

The European Union and the United States reaffirmed their commitment to collaboration and coordinated action on development. The European Union and the United States pledged to continue cooperation on food security, climate change and the Millennium Development Goals, including health, within the framework of the EU-US Dialogue on Development.

The European Union and the United States also welcomed their deepening partnership on a wide range of transnational security issues that affect their citizens. Recognising this, as well as the growing challenge of cyber-security and cyber-crime, the European Union and the United States established an EU-US Working Group on networks and cyber-security, which will report progress within a year. We aim to facilitate transatlantic travel for the citizens of our 27 Member States and of the United States while pursuing the vital task of maintaining security, and now look forward to similar success in our forthcoming negotiations on a Passenger Name Record agreement. We will also continue our work towards negotiating a comprehensive agreement on data protection, with the aim of facilitating cooperation between our respective services while guaranteeing a high level of protection of our citizens’ privacy. We are also committed to extending our partnership on countering violent extremism, in particular by sharing research and good practice and by enhancing cooperation on assistance to third countries at risk.

Finally, we also discussed our common efforts to promote security in certain countries across the world.

 

Question no 15 by Liam Aylward (H-0559/10)
 Subject: The future of the EU Sports Programme
 

Following the meeting of the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council last week, how will the EU Sports Programme evolve over the next 2 years in the absence of a budget?

Does the Council expect funding to be made available to the EU Sports Programme after 2013?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) In 2008(1), the European Parliament called on the Commission to propose an EU programme in the field of sport, as well as preparatory actions in that field. The preparatory actions, which may only run over three consecutive years, have been proposed by the Commission for 2009, 2010 and 2011: the objective of these actions is to prepare future EU actions in the field of sport with a view to implementing the provisions of the Treaty in this field.

The Council has had no involvement in these preparatory actions, which are the responsibility of the Commission and of the European Parliament and have been financed from the margins of a European Parliament budgetary heading since December 2009, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. Under Article 165 TFEU, the EU is granted a new power to support, coordinate and supplement Member States’ action in the field of sport, in particular with regard to social inclusion and integration, sport for health and volunteering.

On 10 May 2010, the Council held a general debate on the future of EU sport policy, thus helping the Commission in its efforts to draft future practical proposals aimed at implementing the new provisions of the Treaty. The following were designated as priority areas by the Council: social inclusion in and through sport, health-enhancing physical activity, education and training in sport, the fight against doping, good governance, structured dialogue with the sports movement, and the sport economy and sport statistics.

Furthermore, on 18 and 19 November 2010, the Council, acting on an initiative of the Belgian Presidency, adopted a resolution on the structured dialogue on sport, conclusions on the fight against doping and conclusions on the role of sport in society.

Although the Commission intends to propose a new framework, on the basis of an EU programme on policy-making and cooperation in sport in the coming years aimed at implementing the new provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon in that field, to date no specific proposal (whether a ‘mini’ programme covering the period 2012-2013 or a comprehensive programme covering the period 2014-2020) has been submitted to the Council by the Commission.

In the absence of proposals from the Commission, the Council is unable to take any action.

 
 

(1) European Parliament Resolution of 14 April 2008 on the White Paper on Sport.

 

Question no 16 by Anni Podimata (H-0566/10)
 Subject: Exchange rate deliberations with a view to the G20 summit
 

The question of exchange rates and competitive devaluation by a number of countries at international level, resulting in massive currency fluctuations, is a major item on the international political agenda. Many place this in the same context as the recent quantitative easing by the US Federal Reserve in the wake of the monetary policy being followed by China for some time now.

Given the highly unstable situation, accompanied by widespread fears of exchange rate intervention and the undeniable impact it could have on the competitiveness of the euro zone countries in economic terms, what is the position of the Council regarding the forthcoming G20 summit in particular?

 
  
 

The present answer, which has been drawn up by the Presidency and is not binding on either the Council or its members as such, was not presented orally at Question Time to the Council during the November 2010 part-session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

(FR) The exchange rate should simply be a reflection of the economic fundamentals of a currency. If this mechanism is to work properly, countries must refrain from competitive devaluations.

In an effort to further strengthen the economic pillar of EMU, the European Council of 28-29 October 2010 focused on sustainable growth, employment and competitiveness, which are the fundamentals of the euro area. Special emphasis was placed on fiscal consolidation plans, financial regulatory reform, social cohesion, job creation and the need for further structural reforms.

In preparation for the Seoul G20 summit, the October 2010 European Council discussed the priorities which the representatives of the EU and the EU Member States which are members of the G20 would promote there. Particular attention was given to the issue of rebalancing world growth, and the European Union stressed the need to avoid all forms of protectionism and to avoid engaging in exchange-rate moves aimed at gaining short-term competitive advantages.

The Seoul Summit took due note of these points made by the EU and the Member States that participated in it, and the G20 leaders adopted the ‘Seoul Action Plan’, in which they pledge to ensure ongoing recovery and sustainable growth and to enhance the stability of financial markets, including enhancing exchange rate flexibility to reflect underlying economic fundamentals, and refraining from competitive devaluation of currencies.

 

QUESTIONS TO THE COMMISSION
Question no 23 by Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (H-0526/10)
 Subject: Education reform as part of the ‘Europe 2020’ strategy
 

Improving education levels, reducing early school-leaving and increasing the share of the population having completed tertiary or equivalent education are among the most important objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy.

In her speech on the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, particularly in the field of education, Commissioner Androulla Vassiliou reiterated that one of the main goals was to lower the school drop-out rate to below 10% throughout the European Union.

What specific measures does the Commission intend to take to raise the level of education in Europe and achieve the objective of lowering the school drop-out rate? Does the Commission plan to draw up a specific strategy to improve the level of education so that young people do not leave school early and obtain the best possible qualifications? How much does the Commission intend to invest in future in programmes and initiatives aimed at young people?

 
  
 

(EN) The Commission intends to propose a Council Recommendation on policies to reduce early school leaving. This Recommendation will set out basic guidelines for coherent, comprehensive and evidence based policies against early school leaving. It will provide a reference framework to assist Member States to develop more effective policies against early school leaving, to support them in their implementation, and so to lead to a significant reduction in the rate of early school leaving in all Member States.

Early school leaving is a complex phenomenon and causes leading to drop-out differ between Member States, regions and localities. The proposed Council Recommendation will add value to Member States’ efforts by supporting them in developing policies that identify the causes of and address early school leaving in a lifelong learning perspective, tackle it as a phenomenon that cuts across several related policy areas, involve all stakeholders, and make policy interventions more systematic and consistent.

The Recommendation itself forms part of a wider ambition to improve education and training in Europe. It is part of the Europe 2020 flagship initiative 'Youth on the Move', plays an important role within the 'Agenda for new skills and jobs' and will be implemented in the context of the Open Method of Coordination in education and training (Education and Training 2020 programme and its predecessor).

Both the Lifelong Learning Programme and the European Social Fund have important roles to play in supporting measures to reduce early school leaving. The future funding for both instruments after 2013 will be determined in the context of the future financial perspectives and the adoption of specific new legal bases for them.

 

Question no 24 by Brian Crowley (H-0554/10)
 Subject: The Erasmus Mundus programme
 

Can the Commission outline what strategies it is pursuing to increase levels of participation in the Erasmus Mundus programme in the EU?

 
  
 

(EN) The only means to increase the overall number of beneficiaries of the Erasmus Mundus programme, given the full absorption rates of existing funding, would lie in a budget increase. Any occasional increases in funding have been quickly absorbed by stakeholders and have been quickly turned into deliverable and measurable outputs on the ground through, for example, an increase in the number of scholarships or joint programmes.

Since its inception in 2004, the European Commission has put in place measures to ensure a satisfactory participation of EU higher education institutions in the programme. Every year it has organised information days in Brussels, which are specifically addressed to universities interested in participating in the programme. In addition, national information days take place yearly in the different Member States. The Commission also organises Erasmus Mundus coordinators meetings to share information and exchange good practice.

Extensive information is also provided on a website, including a detailed description of the programme's actions, information on the ways to apply and relevant documents (programme decision, programme guide, call for proposals, financial and administrative handbooks, and so on).

Considering the very high application rate by EU higher education institutions and the consequently rather low success rate of applications (around 13% for joint masters courses and 7% for joint doctorate programmes), the Commission does not consider it necessary to increase the level and the scope of its promotional actions within the EU.

Concerning the participation of individual European students in the programme, there have also been no difficulties in absorbing the entire budget for EU scholarships. However, a higher application rate would have ensured stronger competition and subsequently a broader choice of more qualified beneficiaries. The Commission, with the support of the Erasmus National Agencies, has therefore launched an information campaign on the opportunities that the programme offers EU students, including by providing information to organisations such as all Erasmus University Charter holders, university associations(1), student associations(2) and the Erasmus coordinators’ association.

 
 

(1) EUA, Coimbra, Santander, UNICA.
(2) EMA, Erasmus Student Network, European Students’ Union, AEGEE.
